The SECOND SECRETARY is trying to be annoyed. Outside the sun is shining, it is early spring and the fi leaves are appearing on the trees. The door opens and BABY-FACE FITZROY puts his head round
[[Excuse me, sir, I-]] [I say ...]
[[Ah, Mr Fitzroy, I was just about  to summon you. Come in.]] [Oh, Baby- Face, I want you a moment.]

CLIVE and EDITH are packing. The window is half open to the garden. The sun is shining but the stove is still burning for it is cold out of the  rays of the sun.  EDITH is very quiet and subdued, notice so to anyone but CLIVE, who is whistling noisily. His  moustache is coming on nicely although it does not yet hi the scar. Each time he comes within range of the mirror,  CLIVE takes an approving look at the new moustache.   EDITH is just packing some handkerchiefs when CLIVE stops her and takes them.
Half a mo'! Those belong to Theo.  Put them with the alarm-clock. (EDITH does so.) How's your own packing going? (Looks at watch.)
(She finds it difficult  to speak) Not far.
Well, you'd better hurry up then.
([Tearful]) I'll be all right.
Don't be so sure. We've only got  half an hour if we are going to call  at the Embassy first. I can manage  here. Come on, stop mooning about!
(Tearfully and angrily) I'm not mooning about!
Keep your hair on! (He stares.) I say, old girl, what's up?
She turns away. He revolves round her with a bewildered l peers in her face. She looks back at him. She is crying. CLIVE is frightfully taken aback and quite helpless.
Edith! I say - Edith! What's the  matter? It's not because I didn't  call for you yesterday, is it? You  know В— Frau von Kalteneck left last  night for the South.
(Sobbing) Did she?
But you knew she was going!
I'd forgotten...
I can't help it if you don't like  horses, can I?  We went to see her  racing-stables - she has some fine  [[horses]] [beasts] but they're too  fat. Edith! do stop crying! Suppose  somebody comes in.
(With feminine logic) Nobody will come in...
Look!  I promise to take you out the  first night we're back in London!   [[We'll go to]] 'Her Majesty's'  [Theatre] - 'The Last of the Dandies' -  they say it's [an] awfully good  [show].
(Still sobbing) - I saw - the paper said -
What paper? What do you mean? Is  that what's making you cry?
(Shakes her head) - the paper said - there's a new  play at 'Her Majesty's Theatre' -  called 'Ulysses' - !
The door opens and somebody does come in: NURSE KONIG.  S has an armful of books.  EDITH quickly turns her back.
(To CLIVE) Oberleutnant Kretschmar-Schuldorff  returns your books, Mr Candy. He is  on his way to see you.
(Moving at once) I must hurry!
You'd better! We'll meet in the hall!
Yes. (She has gone.)

CLIVE looks after her with a frown for a moment. Then his face clears. Girls are strange and anyway there will be l of time to find out what's wrong. He looks ruefully at th books, which are all German editions.
What am I going to do with them? I  don't read German.  Miss Hunter got  them for me.
You can present them to our library.

Clever Nurse Erna. (The [[Brunhilde]]  [Mignon] Aria is  whistled outside.) So Clive Candy's name will always  live in a corner at Stolpchensee! (Changes tone.) But I must write my name in them. (He hears the whistle.) Hullo, Theo!
THEO appears at the window. During the first part of the  scene CLIVE is writing his name in the books.
(He speaks a hybrid  language now, like
Kann ich come in?
Certainly, [come in] my old horse. (As THEO climbs  through.) My old steeplechaser!
THEO'S scar is visible on his forehead. Otherwise he is a right. THEO looks round.
Wo ist Edith?
Packing.
(Surprised) Packing?
Well, of course! Und Sie? How much  longer Sie?
Eine week В— or two. (Makes sign with  fingers.) Clive!
Eh?
Edith come here! Translate for us!
I can translate -
(Shakes his head) Nicht das! Very important.
Shall I fetch Miss Hunter?
Now look here, don't disturb her,  she'll never be ready! (To THEO) Ich mussen call at Embassy, old man -  get my ticket nach London.
(Insists, to NURSE
[Ja.] Please!
NURSE KONIG leaves the room. CLIVE does not understand at all. He shrugs despairingly points to the drinks.
Drink?
[Nein.] Not now.
All right. What the blazes is up  with everybody?
(Very sincerely) Clive! You and I friends. Yes or no?
Of course we're friends!
[[Very sorry, but you and I]] [We]  must duel again!
(Stares) Where's your dictionary, old chap?  You must have got two pages stuck  together!
(Smiling) I В— love - your - (He tries to find the  word 'fiancee' but  can't.) Teufel! Your - Miss Hunter В—
(Can't believe his  ears) Say that again!
I - love - your - Miss Hunter!
You're cuckoo!
(Still smiling) [[No]] [No, ich nein 'cuckoo'], you  'cuckoo'! Because Miss Hunter love  me!
CLIVE stares. Gets up. Examines THEO again.  THEO nods. C suddenly smiles.
Congratulations! (He grabs THEO'S hand.) When did it happen? Why don't I know  about it?
(Still smiling) No duel?
Duel? I- (Thumps chest.) Ich!  Fight anyone who tries, to  stop it! Now will you have a drink?
Double drink!
(Pouring) But you know, old man, Edith was  never my fiancee.
Fiancee! The word I not find!
(Handing drink) Not my fiancee! ( (Chinks glasses.) Lovely girl! Sweet girl! (They drink.) But not my fiancee!
[[(Thoughtfully) So?]] [Bottoms up!]
The door opens. NURSE KONIG comes in. She evidently knows has guessed the whole situation.
Have a drink, Nurse Konig! Where's  the fiancee?
He bows to THEO, who bows back.
She can't come down -
Then we go up. Come on, Theo!
They start for the door. Stop with the same idea. Look at each other, turn, pick up bottles and glasses and hurry o
Interior: Nursing Home
EDITH looks like a young woman waitingto have her mind ma up for her. She is not packing.
Edith!
Come in.]
The door flies open and she starts round as THEO and CLIV invade the room, beaming and carrying bottles and glasses One glance at their faces shows her that the ice has been broken.
Edith, my child! I feel like a proud  father!
(Rather faintly) Do you, Clive?  Why?
I have to give you away, don't I?
How did you find out?
Theo told me in fluent Double Dutch.
(Proudly) I told. (To EDITH) Das einzige Wott ich konnte nicht  finden war 'fiancee'.
They all dissolve in laughter.  CLIVE hands round drinks.
A toast! This to the happiness of my  fiancee who was never my fiancee and  of the man who tried to kill me before  he was introduced to me.  Prosit!
They all drink.
(Puts down glass) May I kiss the bride?
Why ask? I have [did] not ask!

EDITH looks at CLIVE. He steps swiftly forward and takes in his arms for the first and last time. They kiss each other. It is an important moment. It is a  brotherly and sisterly kiss; but for a fraction of a seco both close their eyes. When CLIVE'S eyes are open his whole expression has chang Suddenly he has realized the truth.
(Low voice) Goodbye, Clive.
Goodbye, Edith - old girl. I hope  we'll meet again sometime -
I'm sure we shall -
CLIVE turns to THEO and takes his hand. He still holds  EDITH'S. He is just a little drunk.

Now look here, you son of a gun! You  won't understand a word of what I'm  going to say - but I came to Berlin  to find a rat and found two of the  grandest people I ever met. [[I'm a  little bit drunk.]] I leave to you,  you Prussian stiff-neck, this girl  in trust; and if you don't take care  of her I'll raise the whole of England  against you! The Navy will steam up  your stinking Stolpchensee!  I shall  lead the Army down Unter den Linden!  and we'll -
(Laughing) Stop! Kamerad!]]
CLIVE stops, stares, finishes his drink and pours out ano one for himself and THEO. THEO has an inkling of how the land lies. He looks gaily tenderly at them both before he speaks.
(To CLIVE) [Clive,] my English is not very much.  But my friendship for you is very  much.
And I'm sorry that I have to refuse  your invitation to go to'Her Majesty's  Theatre'.]]
Interior: War Office, Colonel Betteridge's Office
Door of Betteridge's office as in Sequences 21-23
I hope it's taught you a damn good  lesson, Candy.
Now inside the office.

Trouble with you young fellows is  you always want to go changing  everything. And what's the result?  You spend all your leave in a nursing  home full of foreigners. You cost  the Treasury a lot of money. You  make the Foreign Office very cross,  yes very cross. And what do you get  for it?  Your beauty's spoilt. You  weren't any fashion plate before.  I'd be surprised if any woman would  look twice at you now.
So would I, sir.
When you were here in January, I  told you very clearly it was not  your concern. It was an Embassy job.
Well, sir, I suppose I thought I'd  take a chance.

A chance? A chance?  You can't afford  to take a chance with your career,  my boy. You are in the Army as a  career, aren't you, not for five  minutes? You were putting up a pretty  good show. You go barging in on this  nonsense and you come pretty near to  getting yourself kicked out. You  don't want to get yourself kicked  out, do you?
No, sir.

Well, let me tell you one thing.  Don't bother your head with things  you don't understand and you won't  go far wrong. Don't go off at half- cock. Keep cool. Keep your mouth  shut. And avoid politicians like the  plague. That's the way to get on in  the Army.
Thank you, sir.
(Moving round the  desk) Care to dine at my club tonight?
Sorry, sir, I'm taking someone to  the theatre.
Pretty?
I haven't met her yet, sir.
You're still a bit cracked, my boy.  Well, I hope you improve as you get  older. And cheer up, my boy.
Yes, sir.
Interior: Her Majesty's Theatre

The new musical play Ulysses by Stephen Phillips is being performed. The scene is Olympus, the Council of the Gods. Zeus despa Hermes to earth with orders to Calypso to free the ship o Ulysses. Background of thunder, etc. The curtain descends with a crashing climax from the orchestra and the effects man.
Father, whose oath in hollow Hell is  heard; Whose act is lightning after  thunder-word; A boon! a boon! - that  I compassion find  For one, the most unhappy of mankind.
How is he named?
Ulysses. He who planned To take the  towered city of Troy-land.
What wouldst thou?
This! That he at the last may view  the smoke of his own fire c ruling  blue.
Where bides the man?
Calypso this long while Detains him  in her languorous ocean-isle.
Father of gods, this man has stricken  blind my dear son Polyphemus, and  with wind, With roaring waves, by me  let him be hurled From sea to sea  and dashed about the world.
Peace, children, and from your shrill  reviling cease!  Hermes, command  Calypso to release Ulysses and to  waft him over seas.  Ulysses shall  return.
Cloud-gatherer, stay!
Yet canst you work in mischief on  the way   , Yet ere he touch at last  his native shore, Ulysses must abide  one labour more.
HOPPY and SYBIL arrive late in their box at this point.]
(In a box) Where's the bar?
Darling, do control yourself.
I say, there's old Suggie.
Really, darling?  Where?
Suggie ... Suggie ... Suggie. (Getting louder, until  he attracts a scowl  from one of the  actors.)
CLIVE, at last, responds.
(Whispers) Who is the girl with Clive, darling?  Do you know her?
(He seems to be  enjoying a secret  joke) As a matter of fact I do.
Well, darling [who is she]?
(Still enjoying his  joke) I believe he met her sister in Berlin -
Darling, why all this mystery? Who  is she?
My niece's governess - a Miss Hunter.
(Whispers to his  companion) [[What is the world coming to?]]  [Wonders will never cease.]
What, Lieutenant Candy?]]
(Indicating girl with  Hoppy) Sybil Gilpin out without her mother!  [And with Hoppy too.]
Oh, didn't you know [,Mr Candy]?  They are married!
Hoppy! Sybil!
Over a month [ago. The family were  quite taken by surprise. It was very  romantic and sudden. They met here  in this very theatre.]
[[And to think that I sent Hoppy to  take my place - ]] [I know,] I seem  to be a born matchmaker.

A brisk tattoo with the front door knocker is bringing PE to the door with dignified haste. PEBBLE is the Head  Parlourmaid of Lady Margaret Hamilton's exclusively femal establishment. PEBBLE opens the door on the chain. CLIVE is outside.
[[Good evening]] [Hello], Pebble!
Master Clive!
She half closes the door, slips the chain and opens it wi CLIVE steps in. They talk in low tones as she closes the  door and takes his things.
Your Aunt is asleep.
[[Never mind, Pebble. Don't wake  her.]] [All right, don't disturb  her.] I didn't feel like going to  the Club tonight.
You're not sick, Master Clive?
I say, Pebble, how did you feel when  you buried Mr Pebble?
It wasn't so bad at the time, Master  Clive, there was so much to do. It  was after that it got bad, if you  understand me. (CLIVE nods gloomily.) I hope you haven't come from a  burying, sir.
No. From the theatre. But it was the  same thing, in a way.
Was it a sad play?
On the contrary. It was a musical  play. Is the bed in my Den made up?
No, sir, but it won't take a minute  if you don't mind sleeping in  blankets. There isn't time to air  the sheets. Lady Margaret has made  some changes, Master Clive, you'll  see when В—
Pebble! What is going on there?
[[CLIVE signs to PEBBLE not to give him away.
Nothing, Lady Margaret.
You're a liar, Pebble!
LADY MARGARET HAMILTON appears on the landing, carrying a small brass oil-lamp. She is in her night attire.  She is brusque in conversation as in letter-writing.  She sees C
Clive!  How dare you come waking up  the whole neighbourhood at this hour  of the night. Go to your club!
CLIVE smiles and comes running up the stairs to her.
All right. I'm going.
He scoops his aunt up in his arms before she realizes his intention. PEBBLE passes up the stairs smiling.
Did you hear me, nephew? Go to your  club!
Very well. Let's go!
He starts down stairs at a great rate, carrying her as if she were a feather.
(Highly enjoying it) Put me down, you fool!
And I can stay?
I suppose so, since there's no man  here to throw you out.
CLIVE at once runs upstairs and puts his aunt down on the landing again.
How are you, Aunt Margaret?
You may give me a kiss.

It contains all the personal belongings which he really  cherishes.  It's a sportsman's room. He is a keen fisherm and there is a gun-cupboard in one corner. I suppose so, since there's no man  here to throw you out.]
I say? Who put up my South African  heads?

No. [Pebble, do stop fussing like an  old hen and go to your bed.

[Now,] Even money that some  catastrophe has brought you here!
You're on.
Debts?
No.
A woman?
Not exactly.
Explain!
I went to the theatre tonight.
Alone?
With a girl.
And pray why is she 'not exactly'?
Oh, it's nothing to do with her.
Perhaps. [[Who was there?]] See anyone  you know?]
I saw Hoppy with Sybil Gilpin. They're  married!
Certainly. A very suitable match. He  has money, she has land. [And neither  of them has any brains.] You weren't  in love with her, surely?
With Sybil? Oh, no.
I am glad [of that]. She has muscles  like a prizefighter and she[['s bound  to]] ['11] hit Hoppy one day. [[Come  along! I want to show you your Den.]]
(Judicially) Hoppy could give her a couple of  stone.
She will soon make that up, I assure  you! Who is this girl you took to  the theatre?
A Miss Hunter. I met her sister in  Berlin.
Is she nice?
Very. I mean the sister.
Which sister?
The one that stayed in Berlin.
(After a pause, during  which she surveys  him) [Then] the one in London is not so  nice, I take it?
([Pauses]) No.
AUNT MARGARET now knows the whole story.

(Suddenly she changes  her tone) Now [[look here]] [listen], Clive. I  have eighteen rooms here, a bone- idle staff eating their heads off,  and when you come home from South  Africa, you go straight to your Club.
I know. It's awful.

[[I had the walls cleared for your  heads. Now,]] I want you to remember:  wherever you go - whatever you do В—  you've [always] got a home here! And -  whatever you shoot В— there's [always]  room here for them. Look how much  room there is!

CLIVE looks around the big cosy room. He looks gratefully his aunt [[and puts his arm round her shoulders]]. Both of them look up at the heads on the wall. [Clive casts a growing shadow on the wall.] We see the heads, each with its plate, bearing the date a place where the late owner came face to face with the Bri acquisitive instinct. Music starts to play.  The walls become covered with trop from all parts of the British Empire: Trophies: Rhinocero Onyx, Lion, Tiger, Indian Elephant, Sambhur, Tarpon, Mahs Crocodile; Places: British East Africa, Sudan, Rhodesia,  Mysore, Upper Burma, United Provinces, St Helena, Kashmir Ganges Delta;  Dates: 1903, 1905, 1906, 1907, 1910, 1912,1914.  After 19 the wall is blank. The camera shows the bare wall, then swings to show a new trophy. A German spiked helmet, covered in khaki cloth, o the type used in the Great War. The inevitable plate says simply: 'HUN.  FLANDERS, 1918.

The principal reason up to this point for making the pict in colour is because colour is more successful in evoking period which, although some time ago, is still fresh in t memories of many people. We can claim, of course, the pin >odies of the General's Staff in the Turkish Baths and th General's Red Tabs, but these, however attractive, are  decorations. Sights, sounds, but above all, colours, make the memories of a generation: more so in the case of the  period with which we have dealt. 1902 was the commencemen of the Edwardian era, full of charm, prosperity, spacious and leisure, to which it seemed there could never be an e Our next use of colour is in the first part of the 1918В— Sequence which we call for convenience, the 'Khaki Sequen After four years of senseless trench warfare, all the col and variety of Europe and its peoples had been reduced to uniform dull colour by day and to blackness by night. Kha was the colour of clothes, faces, official forms, everyth while the battle zone itself had been reduced to a consis as featureless and as sticky as porridge. By this deliber elimination of all colours except Khaki, we hope to point this contrast.
Exterior: Somewhere in Flanders

It is dusk. It is not raining but it has been and it will again.  An Army staff car, 1918 vintage, is approaching a the road, once a pleasant avenue, now a dreary, cratered  embankment lined with splintered stumps. The continuous thunder of heavy guns sounds in the far  distance.  The car bumps to a stop at the cross-roads.  O the back seat sits COLONEL (Acting Brigadier} CLIVE CANDY He is now a man of forty-two, many ribbons on his chest. moustache is heavy but well cared for, he looks tired but full of energy and devotion to serve his country. He has map spread out on the seat beside him. His driver, [[MULLINS]] [MURDOCH], is also his batman. He about the GENERAL'S age; out since Mons. The landscape, the sky, the car, the men and their mud- plastered uniforms are all one pervasive scheme of khaki. The only Spots, of colour are the GENERAL'S Red Tabs.
This is Dead Cow Cross-roads, sir.
GENERAL CANDY stands up on the back seat of the car and,  through his glasses, examines the landscape.
(Mutters) The question is: whether that is the  Church with the double tower, or the  'Estaminet du Pont'?
Through his powerful glasses we see the featureless mass rubble at which he is looking. God knows what it is.  MUR sits fatalistically.
Damn it, Murdoch, you're supposed to  know the road!
I know it at night, sir. In the  daytime it looks different.
CANDY snorts. MURDOCH suddenly sniffs.
Eh? Got a scent?
Yes, sir. (Sniffs again.) That's our road. I can smell the two  Jerries the Sappers planted.
For'ard then!
Harkaway, sir!
Somewhere in Flanders

We see it in the last dull light of the fading day. The r has started again, a persistent drizzle. All distinguishi features of the Estaminet have either fallen down or fall in long ago. It is gradually vanishing into the mud and n cares.  MAJOR VAN ZIJL is waiting outside in the yard as GENERAL  CANDY'S car drives up. He has a lady's brown silk umbrell against the rain. He is a tough, lively South African of  thirty-four, a veteran of the Boer War. He squelches over the duckboards to the car.
Glad to see you, sir. I've got another  umbrella for you.
He produces. The GENERAL accepts it gratefully.
You've a marvellous eye for loot,  Van Zijl.
Learnt from the English in the Boer  War, sir.
(Chuckles) Where d'you get 'em?
Off JerriesВ—eleven of them-brought  in an hour ago.  Lord knows where  they stole them, they were using  them for camouflage against aircraft.
While talking they have left the car, crossed the duckboa and gone into the Estaminet.
Interior: Estaminet du Pont

The room is now the Outer Office of Battalion H.Q. MAJOR ZIJL is in command. Can see vaguely that once this was a pleasant little cafe just as with some filthy old tramp it is not beyond conje that he was once a young, attractive man. The contrast is great. The room is crowded. Clerks are working and there is a  telephone exchange. Several officers around. As GENERAL CANDY and MAJOR VAN ZIJL enter, everybody stan to attention.
(Saluting) Good evening.
He glances round, starts towards the Inner Office, then s and speaks to VAN ZIJL.
Can we get through to the R.T.O. in  Dupuis-sur-something?
Dupuis-sur-Crois. The Yanks are down  there. How about it, Paddy?
'Fraid the lines broke between us  and 'Mile 14', sir. We can send a  runner.
What message, sir?
Tell him to hold a place on the leave- train. When can I leave here?
Not before dark. They're plastering  the road between 17 and 19 with  shrapnel.
Right. Will someone look after  Murdoch?
Nobby! Paddy, get that runner away!
Yes, sir.
If any of you have got an important  letter or message home, I'll take  it.
Thank you, sir!
CLIVE goes across. VAN ZIJL follows, calling over his  shoulder:
Paddy! I'll [[tackle]] [see] the  prisoners again presently.
Interior: Estaminet du Pont

This was once the large kitchen and chief living room of cafe's owner. You would scarcely guess it now. Its presen function is office of the Battalion Commander.   The GENERAL has heard VAN ZIJL'S last remark. He goes to fire and stands in front of it.
What are these prisoners?
Ulans. The Second Regiment. That's  all I've got out of them so far.
The Second Regiment of Ulans? I'd  like to question them.
(Secretly unwilling) Certainly, sir. (Goes to passage,  yells.) Paddy!  Bring in the prisoners.
Yes, sir.
Any officer with them?
No such luck.
Where did you nab them?

Floating down the river early this  morning. I had a boom across and  netted them like salmon. They had a  hundred pounds of dynamite with 'em.   My guess is they were after the new  pontoon-bridge below St Mangy.
How the blazes did they get to know  about that?
They took one of our patrols prisoner  day before yesterday.
(Stares) Are you suggesting our fellows talked?
The Germans know how to make them  talk.

A little pause follows.  CLIVE is thinking, a fact betray by a heavy frown and an occasional 'Hm!' He shakes his head as if unwilling to believe something. ZIJL watches him, half affectionately. The slim, dark Sou African is a contrast to the solid Englishman. He produce paper from his pocket.

(Finally speaking) [Well if they are,] They're cracking,  my dear chap. It's a sure sign. Nobody  starts to fight foul until he sees  he can't win any other way. I quite  believe Hindenburg, who I hear said  the other day that until now ' Germany  has used her arms with honour - (After a slight pause.) I admit he said nothing about her  legs.
VAN ZIJL has unfolded the paper, which is printed in Germ
This bears you out, sir.
What?
It was on one of the prisoners.
Let me see it.
It's in German.
Oh! Well, read it.]]

The door opens and the eleven German prisoners march down the passage and into the room under an escort with fixed  bayonets. The prisoners have none of the colourful appear of the Ulans of 1902. All the same they are defiant altho not arrogant, as Nazi prisoners would be. They remain gra and serious all through the scene. Outside it is almost d and the rain has got heavier. The wind has got up. [[When the prisoners come in an Orderly brings in three or four  candles stuck in bottles and one oil-lamp with a cracked smoky chimney and no shade. Another Orderly blacks out th windows. The escort lines the prisoners up against the wa During all this action, VAN ZIJL reads aloud from the Ger paper to the GENERAL.

It's an appeal from the 'Erster  General Quartier-Meister', from old  man Ludendorff himself, to his loyal  troops. It starts: 'Soldiers, stand  fast or Germany will lie in the dust.  Should the enemy discover that our  Mannzucht - (He searches for the  word) Our morale is broken, all is lost,  you will have fought and suffered in  vain and the Homeland will hear the  tramp of the invader.' What do you  think of that, sir?
